Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation through Innovations for Institutional and Educational Transformation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This award will fund the Association of Women in Science (AWIS) to conduct a series of three annual workshops for grant awardees from the ADVANCE and Research on Gender in Science and Engineering programs. This will be the first time these two communities will be brought together. Their research has much in common and the two groups will learn much from each other. Overlapping areas of interest include: examination of the causes and strategies to alleviate under-representation of girls and women in STEM, the use of theory-based intervention models to redress under-representation, and the design and carrying out of evaluation of the impact of their programs. The cross-fertilization between the two communities will generate better ideas that can be tested, and mechanisms to evaluate the resulting strategies to learn why they are effective and in what context. This series of workshops is expected to have a broad impact on the entire community of researchers interested in the field of broadening participation, as presentations and poster sessions presented at the meeting will be posted on the AWIS website. In addition, AWIS is planning to innovate the use of social media to more broadly disseminate workshop findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this award, the Association for Women in Science (AWIS) planned and coordinated the annual Program Workshop for the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) ADVANCE: Increasing the Participation and Advancement of Women in Academic Science and Engineering Careers (ADVANCE) and Research on Gender in Science and Engineering (GSE) programs in 2015, 2016, and 2017. Both programs emphasize gender equity in STEM fields. ADVANCE aims to improve women’s representation and advancement in academic STEM careers through systemic change initiatives, interventions, adaptation of existing strategies to new institutional contexts, and intersectional research.  GSE seeks to understand and address gender differences in STEM education and workforce participation through research, diffusion of research-based innovation, extension services, and innovation through institutional integration. While both programs focus on improving gender equity in STEM, they also have variation in their approaches, settings, and stated goals. The centrality of gender and diversity at the intersection of institutional transformation and educational practices binds the NSF ADVANCE and GSE programs together, while the focus on organizational and instructional levels makes them distinct. It is vital to leverage knowledge and build communities of mutual interest among the leaders of both ADVANCE and GSE programs, communities that reflect common interests that are embedded in each yet not immediately present in the casual review of their activities. These similarities and differences necessitated a workshop to meet the dissemination, partnership, networking, and professional development needs of both communities. In addition, during this period, the NSF sought to expand its ADVANCE and GSE grantmaking activities to a wider range of institution types.           

AWIS’ objectives for the Program Workshop series were to facilitate the dissemination of innovations funded by ADVANCE and GSE programs; broaden attendance to include grantees and potential grantees from a variety of Minority-Serving Institutions, community colleges, and other spaces impacting STEM education and workplace issues; create greater connection between ADVANCE and GSE communities; offer professional development opportunities for researchers and practitioners in attendance; share promising practices and research and evaluation findings and techniques; and provide a space for partnership and connection opportunities.

With the help and guidance of a Program Planning Committee comprised of members representing the diversity of perspectives from the ADVANCE and GSE programs, AWIS identified workshop topics, themes, panelists, poster presenters, and expert keynote speakers; recruited a diversity of attendees from a variety of organizations, including national labs, scientific and professional societies, Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs), Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), community colleges, and more; established two-day agendas with a range of session types, including plenaries, breakout sessions, poster sessions, lightning talks, learning labs, joint interest sessions, office hours with program officers, new grantee meetings, and more; and designed evaluation surveys to allow for us to adjust the program from year to year to meet the needs of the attendees.

In total, 823 participants attended the three workshops, 90% of whom were satisfied with the overall program and agreed they could put the information to use in their research and practice. Each workshop allowed participants to present papers, obtain publications, make important connections, learn about trends in research and programs, gain new information about funding opportunities, meet leaders in the field, and conduct organizational business. During the award period, AWIS featured the work of ADVANCE and GSE grantees in issues of the AWIS Magazine, with 15 new article publications for grantees. In addition, AWIS hosted ADVANCE and GSE grantees in 16 free, public webinars, allowing them to expand the dissemination of their work to a broader audience.

This project successfully facilitated the dissemination of innovations funded by the NSF ADVANCE and GSE programs and the insights gleaned from their research and change-oriented strategies into expanded realms. To learn more about the program agenda, presenters, and attendees from each year, please visit: the Program Workshop webpage.
